title: $KMI Kinder Morgan Q1 2025 Earnings Conference Call

rawLines.text: welcome to the quarterly earnings
conference call At this time all
participants are in listenonly mode
During the Q&A session if you'd like to
ask a question you may press star one on
your phone Today's call is being
recorded If you have any objections
please disconnect at this time I'll now
turn the call over to Mr Rich Kinder
executive chairman of Kinder Morgan
Thank you You may begin Uh thank you Ted
Before we begin I'd like to remind you
as we always do that uh KMA KMI's
earnings released today and this call
include forward-looking statements
within the meeting of the Private
Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995
and the Securities Exchange Act of
1934 as well as certain non-GAAP
financial measures Before making any
investment decisions we strongly
encourage you to read our full
disclosures on forward-looking
statements and use of non-GAAP financial
measures set forth at the end of our
earnings release as well as review our
latest filings with the SEC for
important material assumptions
expectations and risk factors that may
cause actual results to differ
materially from those anticipated and
described in such forward-looking
statements On several of these investor
calls I've expressed my view and that of
other leaders and experts in our
industry about the potential for
extraordinary growth in the demand for
natural gas in America and abroad This
optimistic view of the market and its
favorable impact on the growth and
prosperity of midstream energy companies
like Kinder Morgan was embraced during
the last year or so by a significant
number of investors and analysts That
view seemed to accelerate with the
perceived opportunity for natural gas to
fuel AI and data centers Recently that
optimistic view has been questioned by
some on a couple of different grounds
First in the aftermath of the deep sick
ann seek announcement it seemed to some
critics that growth in gas demand for
data centers and electric power in
general was too optimistic Secondly the
announcement of expanded tariffs by the
Trump administration inspired others to
question whether this would result in
less demand for US LNG thereby reducing
the amount of feed gas required in this
country Let me try to put all of this in
perspective by detailing how we view the
drivers of natural gas demand growth
over the rest of this decade Let's start
with some history as prologue to the
future In 2005 US demand for natural gas
was approximately 60 BCF a day In 2024
that demand was almost 109 BCF a day an
increase uh of roughly 80% That's pretty
astounding growth over that 20ear span
Now let's look at the future growth
between now and the end of this decade
with all due deference to Mark Twain's
famous quip that making predictions is
very difficult especially if they
concern the future Most estimates of
growth between now and 2030 range
between 20 and 28 BCF a day and our
internal projections also fall in that
range The overwhelming driver of that
growth is increased LG export demand We
estimate that growth to be somewhere
around 16 BCF a day with the great bulk
of that coming from facilities already
under construction or that have been FID
To FID a project means it is supported
by long-term contracts with creditw
worthy entities Otherwise these
facilities simply could not be financed
I might add parenthetically that our
contracts with LG export facilities are
also supported by long-term contracts
But notwithstanding those facts the
naysayers argue that a trade war with
China will lead to a demunition in need
for US LNG In response let me mention
two counterveailing factors First China
has not imported any US LNG since
February And yet feed gas demand is
setting records averaging 15.5 BCF a day
in the first quarter and approaching 17
BCF a day on several recent days
Secondly our view is that any loss of
the Chinese market will be more than
offset by the efforts of governments in
the U EU and Asia to increase the
imports of US LNG to reduce trade
imbalances and put themselves in a
better negotiating position with regard
to US tariffs South Korea and Indonesia
for example are already in specific
discussions on that strategy And
regarding the EU we believe Europe's
apparent and off-stated reluctance to
ever again allow Russia to be the
dominant supplier of natural gas to
Europe will obviously increase its use
of US LNG Based on all these factors we
remain very bullish on growth in US LG
exports Now in addition to growth in LG
feed gas demand we see NISK upticks in
exports to Mexico power demand driven in
part by the surge in AI and data centers
and residential commercial use
Anecdotally the new projects we have
announced at Kinder Morgan over the last
couple of quarters are supported in
large part by long-term contracts with
utilities in the southeastern US An
indication of the need for more gas to
feed electric generation The point of
all this detail is to put into pers
perspective the drivers of demand for
the product we transport so that any
intelligent investor can make a reasoned
assessment of the natural gas market for
the rest of this decade and not be
whipsawed by the perceived ups and downs
of just one or two facets of the growth
story In truth that growth is supported
we believe by an array of factors that
reflect the strength of natural gas as
an important source of energy for years
to come And with that I'll turn it over
to Kim Okay Thanks Rich Uh we had a good
quarter Uh the financial results which
David will take you through are
essentially in line with our
expectations for the year We currently
expect to exceed budget by at least the
contribution from the outri out
outrigger acquisition Our natural gas
performance versus budget is very strong
In the first quarter we saw record
natural gas demand with demand in the
market growing by 6.8 billion cubic feet
a day driven by a 10% increase in
residential and commercial demand and a
15% increase in LG demand Future natural
gas fundamentals continue to be strong
with demand expected to grow between now
and 2030 as Rich just took you through
And I would add that even if a portion
of the roughly $7 trillion dollar in new
US investment the administration has
announced occurs we believe that would
drive demand that is not currently
captured in
projection During the quarter we added
approximately 900 million to our project
backlog taking the backlog to 8.8
billion after adjusting for the projects
placed in service Of the 900 million
over 70% is primarily focused on serving
power demand The largest project bridge
is a $430 million extension of our Elba
Express pipeline supported by a 30-year
contract It will deliver about $325
million cubic feet a day into South
Carolina to primarily serve increased
power demand and is easily expandable to
over a BCF a day Of course there's been
a lot of attention paid to tariffs At
this point we do not believe that the
tariffs will have a significant impact
on project economics for our new large
projects Mississippi Crossing South
System Expansion 4 Trident GCS and
Bridge that together comprise
approximately 2/3 of our backlog We
currently estimate the impact of tariffs
to be roughly 1% of project cost We've
worked to mitigate the potential impact
by pre-ordering certain equipment
negotiating caps on tariff impacts and
securing domestic steel and mill
capacity For these projects we've locked
in the cost of the finished steel pipe
and less than 10% is exposed to tariffs
In addition to the extent we get some
permitting relief there may be the
opportunity to bring these projects or
portions of the project in service
earlier than planned helping to offset
any impact of tariffs From an operations
perspective we're still in the process
of evaluating the impact of tariffs but
we don't expect it to be material to
2025 but the uncertainty um of tariffs
along with commodity prices did cause us
to be a little bit more conservative in
communicating our outlook for the year
at this point During the quarter we
closed on the previouslyannounced 640
million acquisition of the Bachan
gathering and processing system which
nicely complements our existing assets
in that basement When you look at the
results for the quarter there isn't much
impact from this acquisition given that
we only owned it for 45 days and all the
transaction costs were expensed in the
quarter But it is performing in line
with our
expectations Despite the volatility in
the market we have a very resilient
business Almost twothirds of the EBIT
dot is generated from takeray contracts
Roughly 30% is feebased or hedge with
only 5% of our EBIT die exposed to
commodity prices We expect to continue
to generate nice cash flow and fund our
attractive backlog of projects which are
substantially backed by long-term
contracts from creditworthy entities
while maintaining a strong balance sheet
Finally on management succession Paul
Martin has announced his intention to
retire in January 2026 at which time he
will assume an advisory role to the
board of directors and to the office of
the chairman In that role he will
continue to help the company execute on
our tremendous backlog of natural gas
projects At that time Dax Sanders who
many of you already know will succeed
Tom as president Dax is currently
president of product of the products
business segment and has a thorough
understanding of the company having been
here for approximately 23 years and
served in a variety of different roles
Tom and Dax will start the transition
process in August at which time Mike Gwe
will become president of products
pipeline This is the plan we
contemplated and prepared for in our
succession planning And with that I'll
turn it over to Tom to give you more
details on the business performance for
the quarter
Thanks Kim Starting with the natural gas
business unit transport volumes were up
3% in the quarter versus the first
quarter of
2024 with new peak day volume record set
on four of our five largest pipeline
systems due to the confluence of all the
major demand drivers that is residential
commercial power and LG during prolonged
cold weather in our major market areas
in Texas Louisiana the Midwest and the
East Natural gas gathering volumes were
down 6% in the quarter compared to the
first quarter of 2024 driven primarily
by lower Hannesville production
Sequential total gathering volumes were
down
2% Our producer customers are still
ramping back up after the lower gas
prices in Q2 through Q4 2024 For the
full year we expect our gathering
volumes to average 5% above
2024 but 2% below our 2025 budget We
anticipate gathering volumes will grow
over the balance of 2025 given the
higher price environment producer
conversations and plans and the need for
increased production to meet storage
refill demand and LNG demand growth that
is ramping up throughout the year
Looking forward we continue to see
significant incremental project
opportunities across our natural gas
pipeline network to expand our transport
and storage capabilities in support of
the growing natural gas
market In our products pipeline segment
refined products volumes were up 2%
Crude and condensate volumes were up 4%
in the quarter compared to the first
quarter of 2024
For the full year 2025 refined product
volumes are forecasted to be up about 2%
higher than 2024 but flat with
budget In March 2025 KMI placed its
approximately $17 million Florida jet
fuel expansion project into service to
enhance jet fuel deliveries to the
Orlando Florida market The expansion
creates a continuous jet fuel system
that increases pipeline transportation
capacity into the Orlando International
Airport providing a faster return to
service solution following hurricane
related power outages The project is
fully contracted with 10-year
commitments from the Orlando Airline
Consortium In our terminals business
segment our liquids lease capacity
remains high at 94% Though refining
cracks and blending margins have
softened they remain supportive of
strong rates and utilization at our key
hubs at the Houston Ship Channel in New
York Harbor Our Jones Act tanker fleet
is fully leased today 97% lease through
2025 and 94% lease through
2026 assuming likely options are
exercised
We have opportunistically chartered a
significant percentage of the fleet at
higher market rates and extended the
average length of firm contract
commitments to four
years The CO2 segment experienced
slightly lower oil production uh
production volumes about 1% 5% higher
NGL volumes and 7% lower CO2 volumes in
the quarter versus the first quarter of
For the full year 2025 oil volumes are
for forecasted to be 1% below 2024 but
2% above
budget In March 2025 KMI placed its
Autumn Hills RNG facility into service
The plant's capacity of8 BCF of RNG
annually now brings KMI's total RNG
capacity up to 6.9 BCF per year With
that I'll turn it over to David Michaels
All right Thank you Tom For the quarter
we're declaring a dividend of 29.25
cents per share which is a $1.17 per
share annualized and 2% up from last
year's
dividend During the first quarter we
generated net income attributable to KMI
million down 4% from the first quarter
of last year We generated EPS of 32
cents down 1 cent from last year Much of
that decline is attributable to
unfavorable marktomarket on hedges that
have not yet settled and we treat as
certain
items On an adjusted net income basis
which excludes those certain items we
generated $766 million and adjusted EPS
of 34 cents up 1% and flat from last
year
respectively This quarter growth was
driven by greater contributions from our
natural gas terminals and CO2 businesses
Our main growth drivers were
contributions from our Texas intrastate
natural gas system attractive capacity
sales and park and loan services on our
interstate natural gas assets greater
renewable natural gas production and
higher contributions from our Jones Act
tankers I would note that some of the
natural gas agreements we entered into
during the first quarter extend beyond
the first quarter and therefore
therefore will add contributions during
the remainder of the year
These were offset by lower gathering and
processing volumes as Tom mentioned uh
the impact from our planned splitter
facility turnaround uh and lower ren
pricing uh in our renewable natural gas
businesses Moving on to our balance
sheet we ended the quarter with $ 32.8
billion of net debt and 4.1 times net
debt to adjusted Ebida which is in the
middle of our leverage target range of
three and a half to four and a half
times The 4.1 times only includes a
month and a half of Ebida from our
outrigger but it includes all of the
acquisition funding So that metric will
decline will improve as we add more
quarters of the outrigger
contribution Our net debt increased by
just over a billion dollars from the
beginning of the year And here's a a
high level reconciliation of that
change We had a working capital use of
about three a little bit more than $300
million Uh that working capital deficit
is made up of interest expense payments
and the first typical first quarter
payments of bonus and property
tax We generated cash flow from
operations of $1.16 billion We paid
dividends of $650
million We uh expended uh $770 million
of total capex
We closed on the outrigger acquisition
which was approximately $650 million and
we posted collateral for some of our
natural gas uh hedges of about $90
million which gets you close to the the
billion dollar increase in net debt for
the year for the full year As Kim
mentioned while it's still early in the
year we expect to exceed budget by at
least the contribution from the
outrigger
acquisition And as disclosed in our
fullear budget our budgeted adjusted
EBIT dog growth was 4% Just including
the outrigger acquisition our EBIT dog
growth would increase to 5% Our adjusted
EPS growth would still remain at an
attractive 10% And we're also expecting
to still end the year with net debt to
adjusted EDOT 3.8
times Most of our 2025 budgeted growth
comes from expansion projects
Uh now that we're more than a quarter
into the year we can say we're on target
to place the vast majority of these
expansion projects in service on time
and on budget or with only minor
variances The largest expansion
contributions come from our evangel
evangelene path pro expansion project
which is on track to come online this
summer and multiple projects on our
Texas intrastate system The largest of
which include our South Texas to Houston
project which is near completion and a
couple of additional projects that have
already been placed into service
including our web county and central
Texas expansion So we're off to a good
start to the year Our uh we're on track
to put our expansion projects in service
We're experiencing favorable performance
across our businesses and have
sanctioned additional projects uh that
will drive growth well into the future
Finally uh based on investor feedback we
do not plan to host a regular investor
day presentation uh in person going
forward Uh like we did this year we will
continue to publish an annual company
update which will include our budget for
the year uh but won't host the the
presentation in person Uh we'll also
maintain our objective to pro provide
great transparency to and extensive
engagement with our investors And with
that I'll turn it back to Kim for Q&A
Okay Chad if you'll come back on Uh we
will take questions
Yes the phone lines are now open for
questions If you would like to ask a
question over the phone please press
star one and record your name To
withdraw your question press star two
The first question in the queue is from
Michael Bloom with Wells Fargo Your line
is now open
Thanks Uh good afternoon everyone
um wanted to start uh talking about the
potential uh additional gas pipeline
investments uh that you uh are looking
at with utilities and data centers How
would you characterize the pace of
discussions with customers I guess since
the last earnings call
uh Michael this is Seth Yes So uh one I
think as it pertains to data centers uh
you know there's still as we we try to
determine kind of the sites specific
locations that they're looking at where
we you it's still evolving uh as it
pertains to the utilities that are
supporting some of these data centers Uh
as you can see we're actively pursuing
opportunities to provide supply uh to to
ultimately feed these upcoming data
centers And so you know I would say the
activity level is pretty strong Uh you
know there's a lot of competition out
there across the network Um we we feel
like we're positioned well Uh you know
as we talk about bridge into South
Carolina you know this is just kind of
step one Uh the platform for growth has
been established and we see you know
some incremental opportunities around
power and potentially data centers there
as we've got the straw put in
So and I'll I'll just add a couple of
things to that one if you look you know
at the at the additions to the backlog
you know this quarter I said
approximately 70%
um of those are related to power so you
know sometimes it's hard to
differentiate between you know what's
data center related and what's power
because the power could be going to to a
data center I'd also say if you look at
our our total backlog like 50% of the
projects in our overall backlog are
related to to power where We have seen I
think the most act concrete activity to
date on data centers has been largely
the regulated utilities so far Now
there's a you know there are lots of
discussions going on as um as Seth said
a lot of those discussions are are
happening across the southern United
States and you know that's an area where
we are particularly well positioned
Thanks for all that uh that was really
helpful Maybe if I could just uh drill
down on on one particular area or region
Um can you get provide an update on any
progress in Arizona
uh regarding either an expansion of EPNG
or or Greenfield project or just how you
see that that area developing thanks
Sure Michael So uh one we we see a need
uh out in the desert southwest Arizona
included Uh we have been you know
pursuing both brownfield and green field
opportunities We're trying to look at
that Obviously if we're in a competitive
situation here um as we get you know if
we get any progress here from a customer
standpoint we'll make those
announcements at the time But I can tell
you there's there's there is interest uh
and we do see there we do see a need uh
out west uh especially the state of
Arizona
The next question
Chad we'll take the next question
Yes the next question is from Jeremy
Tanette with JP Morgan Your line is open
Hi good afternoon Good afternoon Uh
maybe pick it up on Arizona if you could
and the potential for expansion further
west Just wondering the docket that was
opened in February the natural gas
infrastructure and storage docket uh
that vice chair opened Are you expecting
anything you know specific out of there
that will inform your views of the far
as timing and sizing of expansion
further west and uh just as you look
even further out I think that there EA 2
could be on the horizon and we'll need
to source gas as well It seems like EPNG
would be uh in play there So just
wondering those two dynamics any
thoughts you could share
well uh just once again I'm going to
keep it broad just because you know
we're we are in a very competitive
situation but uh both you know
the overall demand is we see coming
right and I think really both both the
the doc you're talking about and and our
through our conversations with our
customers point to the need for
incremental capacity needs Uh and you
mentioned EKA you know that that's a
longerterm play possibly but all of that
bodess to the need for incremental
capacity and and and and how we get
there ultimately be decided by our
customers and the contracts that they
sign Yeah And I let me just make a
couple of points overall I mean look um
there's the potential for data center
development and in in Arizona I think
the Arizona utilities need more power
especially with all the the population
migration from California and other
places into Arizona You know I think
Mexico has a couple of power plants on
the other side of the border that
they're going to need natural gas for
And you've got you know the LG potential
off the west coast So you know there's a
lot of uh good demand uh factors Our
pipeline EPG is full And so I think you
know to to do something out there you
would have to twin it Um but it is you
know it is a a nice opportunity and the
demand drivers that are present in you
know that we're talking about here on
the west are what we're seeing you know
broadly across our whole network and and
one more thing to add you know it's not
necessarily just a green field
opportunity right there There are sign
you know we are looking at brownfield
opportunities smaller expansions that
may make sense to unlock incremental
capacity into the base
Got it That's very helpful there And
then just a higher level macro question
if it could you know we've seen WTI uh
dip towards 60 and you know briefly uh
you know below 60 here and uh you know
concerns with regard to potential
economic weakness ahead as as Rich
talked about in the opening comments
there Just wondering as far as your
conversations with your producer
customers uh any any change in tone
there uh such as if you know WTI does
step down into the 50s and stays there
for a while and basins that have uh
liquids driven economics if you think
that there could be changes in producer
activity there and how how that could
impact KMI although it's a smaller part
of the business
Yeah I mean you know our gathering
business I think is roughly 8% of our
overall business Um and you know if you
look at it to date you know I think it's
too early to to make any calls Um you
know we haven't the conversations that
we have had with our producers they
haven't made any changes Um you know I'd
say if you look at our gathering assets
you've got the Bakan which is is oil
based but Goss are going up Um and then
you obviously are you know one of our
largest positions um is also in the
Hannesville And there that's a dry
natural gas play Um and I'd say that you
know the conversations there with our um
with our customers as Tom alluded to
earlier have been more bullish where
what they're talking about is
potentially adding rigs um beyond what
we uh we expected previously Now that'll
take time and we won't see that benefit
um till later in the year But I'd say
you know there is uh the natural gas
side has been I think stronger um than
the conversations have been stronger
than what we were originally expecting
Yeah And I guess you know to add one
more comment to that when you think
about our our our geographic basins that
we're we have our gathering systems in
most of our acreage is in kind of the
you know the connections that we're on
with tier one acreage So if you go back
to when we were in COVID you know I
think we we we stood the storm pretty
well uh from a price standpoint uh even
in our liquid plays uh and and the
natural the natural offset as Kim was
mentioning is is the dry gas plays when
when that happens What we do see is we
do see gas demand increasing and so if
the associated gas capac if the
associated gas kind of tapers off a
little bit even though we didn't see
that we actually saw goss increase when
when when crude fell off uh we we we'll
see a pickup in the Hanesville and and
the dry gas Eagleford plays uh because
the demand has to be met
Got it Thank you for that
The next question in the queue is from
Manav Gupta with UPS Your line is
open Uh good afternoon My question here
is a little bit you know energy equities
in general has started pricing in a
little bit of a recession You touch a
lot of end markets whether it's gas or
refined products even jet fuel in your
system Are you seeing any early signs of
recessionary demand or what we see in
the market is just volatility the
underlying demand in your system is
holding up pretty well
Well I mean I'd say a couple of things
on that Um so far I think we're holding
up pretty well Um but you know refined
product volumes in the quarter were up
2% Um you know we saw strong natural gas
demand I think we're going to continue
to see strong natural gas demand because
a and growing natural gas demand over
the course of the year because a lot of
what is driving that is is going to be
the export LNG and you know that those
volumes are coming on and uh and a lot
of those have you know taker contracts
associated with them So I think you're
going to see the uptick in in gas demand
over the course of of the year And as
Tom said we've got to we've got to
refill storage So one I think we're too
early Um and two I think you know when
you look at natural gas which is 60% of
our business you know I think there's
some different factors that you really
have to to consider there than just you
know US recessionary pressures that
drive that demand
Thank you My quick followup here is can
we get some more details about this new
bridge project that you added to the
backlog and the reason I'm asking is
last year you announced the Mississippi
crossing project and and within one
month you ended up upsizing the project
So what's the possibility of you
upsizing this bridge project thank you
Well uh look the possibilities are great
but I'm not going to comment on the
timing Uh you know obviously our
customers are going to dictate when we
expand I will tell you South Carolina is
one of the fastest growing states that
we see out there Demand is growing on
from a power side from a from a
residential need standpoint Uh and uh
you know like I said the opportunity set
around potential data centers could be
there So I think overall uh we feel like
we're positioned well for future growth
Um the platform's there now Uh this
helps us establish the platform once
this project's completed and uh we're
we're excited uh about the the
opportunity in South Carolina
Thank you so much
Next question in the queue is from John
Mai with Goldman Sachs Your line is open
Hey team thanks for the time Uh I wanted
to pull a couple of these together Um
you know I think in the last call you
kind of m made the comment of saying
"Hey we've we've done a lot of very big
project announcements Maybe the pace of
those will slow." I think you showed
today that you're still able to add you
know a ton of small to mediumsized ones
to keep adding to that backlog Is this
you know not to put you on the spot was
this a outsized kind of win or is this
the kind of you know more regular away
kind of backlog additions we could uh
expect to see from here yeah I mean it
it's hard uh to predict I think what
exactly what we're going to be adding to
the backlog but you know as you know
we've been saying this whole call I mean
the demand drivers behind the natural
gas industry which is over 60% of our
business are very strong you know
whether you look at you know LG and and
Rich pointed out there that you know if
you look the LG demand is expected to
double and most of that is um going to
be driven by projects that are FID or
under construction And then he also
pointed out you know that some of these
uh as we go through tariff negotiations
with some of these countries um that
them buying natural gas from the US may
be a way that they solve the the balance
of payments with the US Um and so even
if you know you're in a uh potential
trade war with China there's other
demand that could make up for that or uh
actually be greater than what the demand
coming out of China would be because as
Rich pointed out they haven't been
taking very much and and natural and the
LG demands been over 17 BCF the setting
record You know I think you know from
the perspective of power and AI when you
look at AI you know I think that is
going to be in our national security
interest um to win the the AI race And
so I think you know you'll continue to
see demand for AI and I think also as
the cost there you know we rich talked a
little bit about deep speak but I think
what you're hearing and what we've heard
from a lot of the technology players is
as the cost of that technology comes
down you we would expect more people to
use it and so that demand uh that demand
driver is firmly in place and then if we
get more American manufacturing and
investment I think um you know that will
five uh demand growth for natural gas So
I think you know you look at that and
you say so what does your outlook for
projects look like and I it continues to
be a robust out outlook and I will tell
you that you know the we've added you
know 900 on a growth basis uh to the to
the backlog um uh you know today there
there's another $400 million of projects
that our board approved today roughly
400 million you know that we're close to
signing contracts so they approved on a
contingent basis and we haven't added to
the backlog because um we don't add to
the backlog until those contracts are
signed So I think you know you can hear
that I think we feel even in the current
economic environment where there is a
lot of volatility out there we feel very
good about our business and the
opportunity stuff that we have in front
of us Now I would just add that that we
have 70,000 miles of gas pipelines We
move 40% of the gas in America And
beyond that we're located in the right
places Uh all this LG feed gas demand
the great bulk of it is along the Gulf
Coast A great part of the electric
generation growth is also in the
southeastern United States and along the
Gulf Coast So if you just look at where
we operate and the size of our
operations I think there's every
opportunity to expand our positions And
coming back to Seth's answer a couple of
